sen.j: 管野 スガ（かんの すが、1881年（明治14年）6月7日 - 1911年（明治44年）1月25日）は、明治時代の新聞記者・著作家・女性解放運動・社会主義運動家。
sen.e: Suga KANNO (June 7, 1881 - January 25, 1911) was a journalist, writer, feminist and socialist activist in the Meiji era.
Suga KANNO (June 7, 1881 - January 25, 1911) was a newspaper journalist, writer, feminist and socialist activist in the Meiji era.
Suga KANNO (June 7, 1881 - January 25, 1911) was a newspaper journalist, writer, feminist and socialist activist in the Meiji era.
She is also known as Sugako (須賀子).
She is also known as 'Sugako' (須賀子).
She is also known as 'Sugako' (須賀子).

sen.j: 幸徳事件で処刑された12名の1人。
sen.e: She is one of 12 people who were executed in the Kotoku Incident (High Treason Incident).
She is one of 12 people who were executed in the Kotoku Incident (High Treason Incident).
She is one of 12 people who were executed in the Kotoku Incident (High Treason Incident).

sen.j: 名字は「菅野」と書かれる場合もあるが、それは実際には誤りである。
sen.e: Her family name is sometimes written as "菅野" but actually this is incorrect.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Her family name is sometimes written as '菅野' but actually this is incorrect.
Her family name is sometimes written as '菅野' but actually this is incorrect.

sen.j: （江戸時代の頃は「菅野」姓であったが、明治になってからスガの父が「管野」に姓を変更した）
sen.e: In the Edo period the family used "菅野" but Suga's father changed it to "管野" in the Meiji era.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period the family used '菅野' but Suga's father changed it to '管野' in the Meiji period.
In the Edo period the family used '菅野' but Suga's father changed it to '管野' in the Meiji period.
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 1881年（明治14年）、大阪・絹笠町において、裁判官・代言人・鉱山事業家の管野義秀の長女として生まれる。
sen.e: She was born in 1881, the first daughter of Yoshihide KANNO, who was a judge, lawyer and mining business entrepreneur in Kinugasa-cho, Osaka.
She was born in 1881, the first daughter of Yoshihide KANNO, who was a judge, lawyer and mining business entrepreneur in Kinugasa-cho, Osaka.
She was born in 1881, the first daughter of Yoshihide KANNO, who was a judge, lawyer and mining business entrepreneur in Kinugasa-cho, Osaka.

sen.j: 19歳のとき、東京深川の商人小宮福太郎と結婚したが、海軍に身を置くこととなったことを理由として離婚した。
sen.e: At 19 she married Fukutaro KOMIYA, who was a merchant in Fukagawa, Tokyo, but later divorced him because he joined the navy.
At 19 she married Fukutaro KOMIYA, who was a merchant in Fukagawa, Tokyo, but later divorced him because he joined the navy.
At 19 she married Fukutaro KOMIYA, who was a merchant in Fukagawa, Tokyo, but later divorced him because he joined the navy.

sen.j: 離婚後は作家・宇田川文海に師事して文学を学ぶとともに『大阪新報』の記者をつとめ、文海の愛人になった。
sen.e: After the divorce she became a reporter for "Osaka Shinpo" (Osaka News) while studying literature under Bunkai UDAGAWA and became his mistress.
After the divorce she became a reporter for "Osaka Shinpo" (Osaka News) while studying literature under Bunkai UDAGAWA, an author, and became his mistress.
After the divorce she became a reporter for "Osaka Shinpo" (Osaka News) while studying literature under Bunkai UDAGAWA, an author, and became his mistress.

sen.j: その後平民社の堺利彦を訪ね、その紹介で和歌山県田辺市の牟婁新報に入社した。
sen.e: Subsequently Suga met Toshihiko SAKAI in Heimin-sha (The Commoner's News Company) and worked for Muro Shinpo (Muro News) in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Subsequently Suga met Toshihiko SAKAI in Heimin-sha (The Commoner's News Company) and through the good offices of him, she joined Muro Shinpo (Muro News) in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: and worked for → and through the good offices of him, she joined
sen.e: Subsequently Suga met Toshihiko SAKAI in Heimin-sha (The Commoner's News Company) and through the good offices of him, she joined Muro Shinpo (Muro News) in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: ここで知り合った荒畑寒村（勝三）と1907年（明治40年）から同棲し、後に結婚した。
sen.e: From 1907 she cohabited with Kanson (or Katsuzo) ARAHATA, who she met in Muro Shinpo, and they later got married.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From 1907 she cohabited with Kanson (or Katsuzo) ARAHATA, who she met in Muro Shinpo, and they later got married.
From 1907 she cohabited with Kanson (or Katsuzo) ARAHATA, who she met in Muro Shinpo, and they later got married.

sen.j: 赤旗事件で投獄され、出所したのち寒村とは離婚。
sen.e: Suga was imprisoned for the Red Flag Incident ("Akahata Jiken" in Japanese) and divorced Kanson after being released from prison.
Suga was imprisoned for the Red Flag Incident ("Akahata Jiken" in Japanese) and divorced Kanson after being released from prison.
Suga was imprisoned for the Red Flag Incident ("Akahata Jiken" in Japanese) and divorced Kanson after being released from prison.

sen.j: そののち幸徳秋水と同棲しアナーキズムに共鳴する。
sen.e: Afterwards she cohabited with Shusui KOTOKU and began to sympathize with anarchism.
Afterwards she cohabited with Shusui KOTOKU and began to sympathize with anarchism.
Afterwards she cohabited with Shusui KOTOKU and began to sympathize with anarchism.

sen.j: 1910年（明治43年）、宮下太吉、新村忠雄らと天皇暗殺を密謀したとして起訴された。
sen.e: In 1910, Suga was charged with conspiring with Takichi MIYASHITA and Tadao NIIMURA to assassinate the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1910, Suga was charged with conspiring to assassinate the Emperor with Takichi MIYASHITA and Tadao NIIMURA.
sen.cmt: 語順を入れ換えました。
sen.e: In 1910, Suga was charged with conspiring to assassinate the Emperor with Takichi MIYASHITA and Tadao NIIMURA.

sen.j: いわゆる大逆事件の被告となった。
sen.e: She became a defendant of so-called the High Treason Incident.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She became a defendant of so-called the High Treason Incident.
She became a defendant of so-called the High Treason Incident.

sen.j: 判決は有罪・死刑となった。
sen.e: She was found guilty and sentenced to death.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She was found guilty and sentenced to death.
She was found guilty and sentenced to death.

sen.j: 翌1911年（明治44年）1月25日、秋水ら11人が刑死した翌日に刑死した。
sen.e: The following year, on January 25, 1911, she was executed the day after the other 11 people, including Shusui, were executed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The following year, on January 25, 1911, she was executed the day after the other 11 people, including Shusui, were executed.
The following year, on January 25, 1911, she was executed the day after the other 11 people, including Shusui, were executed.
